case_name: National Union of Commercial Employees & Anr. v. M/s. Pereira Fazalbhoy & Co.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1961. APPeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 20, 1958 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2789 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: . APPeal from the judgment and order dated November 20, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2789 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on February 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 13, The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal arises out of a dispute

facts.text: Appellants are National Union of Commercial Employees and another.

anchor.surface_text: between the appellants, the National Union of Commercial Employees Anr, and the respondents Pereira, Fazalbhoy and Desai

facts.text: Respondents Pereira, Fazalbhoy and Desai constitute attorneys firm M/s. Pereira Fazalbhoy Co.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents Pereira, Fazalbhoy and Desai who companystitute an Attorneys firm by name M s. Pereira Fazalbhoy Co.

facts.text: In August 1957, appellant wrote to respondent firm setting forth demands for bonus for 1955-56 and 1956-57 and other matters on behalf of employees.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in August, 1957 the appellant wrote to the respondent firm setting forth certain demands on behalf of its employees. These demands related to bonus for the years 195556 and 1956-57

facts.text: Parties could not agree on demands.

anchor.surface_text: and to certain other matters. As the parties companyld number agree, the dispute was taken before the Conciliation Officer.

facts.text: Dispute taken before Conciliation Officer.

anchor.surface_text: As the parties companyld number agree, the dispute was taken before the Conciliation Officer.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer failed to settle and submitted failure report to Government of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Conciliation Officer also failed to bring about a settlement and so he submitted his failure report to the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: State Government referred dispute regarding bonus for 1956 and 1957 to Industrial Tribunal under section 12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the State Government referred the dispute in regard to the bonus for the two years 1956 and 1957 for adjudication before an Industrial tribunal under section 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act  No. 14 of 1947

facts.text: Respondents raised preliminary objection before Tribunal that their profession is not an industry under the Act, dispute not industrial, reference incompetent, Tribunal no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal, the respondents raised a preliminary objection. They urged that the profession followed by them was number an industry within the meaning of the Act, and so the dispute raised against them by the appellants was number an industrial dispute

facts.text: Tribunal upheld preliminary objection and held no jurisdiction as not industrial dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the companytention was that the dispute number being an industrial dispute under the Act, the reference made by the Government was incompetent and so, the Tribunal had numberjurisdiction to adjudicate upon this dispute. The Tribunal upheld the preliminary objection

facts.text: Appellants filed Special Civil Application No. 2789 of 1958 in Bombay High Court under Articles 226 and 227 challenging Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The order thus passed by the Tribunal was challenged by the appellants before the High Court at Bombay by special Civil Application No. 2789 of 1958 filed under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held respondents firm not an industry, dispute not industrial, reference invalid, Tribunal right, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companysidered the rival companytentions raised before it by the appellants and the respondents and came to the companyclusion that the respondents firm did number companystitute an industry and so the dispute between the said firm and its employees was nut ail industrial dispute

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificate from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and it is with the said certificate that the present appeal has companye to this Court

facts.text: Supreme Court held solicitors firm not an industry under s.2(j) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion it is difficult to accept the plea that a solicitors firm carrying on the work of an Attorney is an industry within the meaning of s. 2 j .

facts.text: Parties agreed dispute determined in light of State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties agreed that the present dispute would have to be determined in the light of the decision of this Court in that case.

facts.text: Respondents firm carries on work of Solicitors in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the short question which it raises for our decision is whether the respondents firm which carries on the work of Solicitors in Bombay can be aid to companystitute an industry

facts.text: Partnership document describes work as business of solicitors.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the document of partnership executed between the different partners of the firm provided, inter alia, that all expenses of the business of the partnership

facts.text: In Hospital Mazdoor Sabha case, Supreme Court held J.J. Group of Hospitals an industry under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the Hospital case  1 , this Court had occasion to companysider whether the services of workmen engaged as ward servants in the J.J. Group of Hospitals, Bombay, under State companytrol were workmen and whether the Hospital Group itself companystituted. an industry

facts.text: Service in hospitals and dispensaries added to First Schedule in 1956 as public utility service.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956, Entry No. 9 among others, was added in the First Schedule specifying another public utility service. This Entry refers to service in hospitals and dispensaries.

arguments.court_reasoning: Solicitors firm not an industry under s.2(j) as per working test requiring direct essential cooperation between employer and employees

arguments.claim: In determining if respondents carry on an industry under s.2(j), distinguish between professional service by individual and by firm of partners; organized institutionalised firm service involves cooperation between employers and employees satisfying Hospital working test

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction not logical as same cooperation exists for individual solicitor employing staff; cannot confine to firm organization

arguments.claim: A solicitors firm does not satisfy the working test from Hospital Mazdoor Sabha as employee cooperation is not direct and essential to the professional service rendered, which depends on solicitor's intellectual equipment; employee work is incidental

anchor.surface_text: When in the Hospital case this Court referred to the Organisation of the undertaking involving the cooperation of capital and labour or the employer and his employees, it obviously meant the cooperation essential and necessary for the purpose of rendering material service

arguments.claim: Liberal professions like attorneys are outside definition of industry under s.2(j) as they lack essential basis of capital-labour partnership; based on intellectual equipment, not active cooperation of employees

arguments.claim: Respondents cannot contend their work is not industry under s.2(j) as their partnership deed describes it as 'business of solicitors'; supported by Dickson v. Jones where solicitors' agreement tested as restraint of trade implying business/trade
arguments.court_reasoning: Use of 'business' is loose sense; does not override working test for s.2(j); restraint of trade test irrelevant to industry definition

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion it is difficult to accept the plea that a solicitors firm carrying on the work of an Attorney is an industry within the meaning of s. 2 j .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solicitors' professional service depends on individual intellectual equipment; employees perform incidental tasks without direct essential cooperation required by Hospital Mazdoor Sabha working test.

holdings.text: The application of the said test to the facts in the present appeal leads to the conclusion that the work of solicitors which the respondents are carrying on as a firm is not an industry under s. 2 j of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm organized superficially like industry but subsidiary employee work has no direct nexus to professional advice rendered to clients.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Individual solicitor employs staff similarly requiring same type of cooperation as firm; test applies equally without distinction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal professions based on intellectual equipment lack essential capital-labour cooperation; not within industrial law scope.

holdings.text: the argument that the respondents themselves have called their work as business is of no assistance
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Business' used loosely in partnership deed; irrelevant to s.2(j) working test; restraint of trade cases do not define industry.

holdings.text: That is the view taken by the Bombay High Court and we think, that view is right

anchor.surface_text: The application of the said teat to the facts in the present appeal leads to the conclusion that the work of solicitors Which the respondents are carrying on as a firm is number an industry under s. 2 j  of the Act. holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court agrees with High Court and Tribunal that firm not industry, dispute not industrial, no jurisdiction.
